title_review: Tiny bit intimidating but worth a look
review_preview: This is a very traditional sherry bar. There were only a few locals inside when I went. Not a tourist in sight. I thought about not going in as it didn't look that friendly. In reality it was completely fine although don't expect to have...
review_full: This is a very traditional sherry bar. There were only a few locals inside when I went. Not a tourist in sight. I thought about not going in as it didn't look that friendly. In reality it was completely fine although don't expect to have a nice chat with the barman.  I only stayed for one drink (I was on my own and wanted to have a quick drink in one of Hemingway’s favourite bars). I had a really delicious Manzanilla and some olives.  If you like Sherry and want to experience an old school Madrid bar, this is the place!

title_review: This is a must visit sherry bar. Not a restaurant
review_preview: Went here for the first time over 21 years ago and made a most enjoyable revisit last week. Although my waist size has extended somewhat over that period I don't think La Valencia has changed much apart from the fact it's under different ownership. Tapas...
review_full: Went here for the first time over 21 years ago and made a most enjoyable revisit last week.  Although my waist size has extended somewhat over that period I don't think La Valencia has changed much apart from the fact it's under different ownership.  Tapas wise it is quite limited, although we did have some delicious bright green olives and some raw, but cured tuna. The reason to come here however is not the food - it's the sherry. Now I know what you're thinking - Sherry, really? Yes really. The sherry here is absolutely wonderful and should certainly make you reappraise it as not being just an old lady's tipple.  This place is well worth tracking down. An authentic classic in a city who's identity is become more and more Americanised.  Just make sure you don't try and take any photos or expect polite conversation from the bar staff.

review_preview: Can you imagine a bar anywhere else in the world that only sold about five variations of the same drink and yet was still really successful? Well it works for La Venencia and clearly has for many years. Nearly everyone in here is Spanish and...
review_full: Can you imagine a bar anywhere else in the world that only sold about five variations of the same drink and yet was still really successful? Well it works for La Venencia and clearly has for many years. Nearly everyone in here is Spanish and while I'm happy that we found it I'm equally glad that it hasn't been overrun by tourists. The atmosphere is friendly, the tapas simple but tasty (the cured tuna especially good) and the sherry sublime. I imagine it looks exactly like it did 50 years ago - the fact it hasn't been tainted by the modern world is definitely part of its charm. Every future trip to Madrid will include an excursion to this fabulous little bar.

review_preview: We stumbled upon this restaurant one afternoon after walking around the city.  We were greeted by a very friendly young man who invited us in.  It was nice and cool, and he seated us by the window, so we could watch the people passing by,...
review_full: We stumbled upon this restaurant one afternoon after walking around the city. We were greeted by a very friendly young man who invited us in. It was nice and cool, and he seated us by the window, so we could watch the people passing by, The restaurant is very nice, clean and stylishly decorated. Our server was very nice, and we ended up having more than one, as only one of them was comfortably fluent in English. He gave us recommendations for lunch, and it was one of the best meals we had. I had Gnocchi and it was delicious. All of us had pasta and we all agreed that it was among the best we've ever eaten. The ingredients tasted so fresh, and the menu had some different twists on conventional meals. We had a good time with the Servers, trying to teach them English, and them trying to teach us Spanish. All in all it was a great lunch..

Juan Pablo helped talk me into their Prociutto and Mushroom and it was exactly what I needed. You could tell it was made in a wood fired oven (the best way) and it was generous in toppings. Even their Tinto de Verano was special with a lil touch of Vermouth. The space itself is STUNNING...I want their blue and yellow chairs for myself. If I lived in Madrid I could definitely see this as one of my regular spots. Thank you Juan Pablo for excellent service and Flavia for an amazing meal!!

review_preview: Like a previous review we were encouraged to enter this place by a pleasant welcome at the door as we walked by and its enticing decor. We asked to sit in a higher dining area with windows to the street but were ushered to another...
review_full: Like a previous review we were encouraged to enter this place by a pleasant welcome at the door as we walked by and its enticing decor. We asked to sit in a higher dining area with windows to the street but were ushered to another area only to see preferred guests being escorted upstairs. Not sure why!  The waiter was very pleasant but ameturish spilling drops of red wine onto the table clothe and around the glass. We were repeatedly told of the establishments prowess in that they bring all fresh ingredients from Italy but sometimes the motto of 'under promise and over deliver' is a better way to go rather than the other way round. My three companions meals were average to good and my Carbonara (an easy staple in most Italian Restaurants) was like eating glue. Once this was pointed out, the waiter agreed it was not to standard and offered a new entree but by that time it was too late as my guest had almost finished. A free desert was kindly offered and my meal was complimentary which was a nice touch. I am not sure how long they have been open but I suspect not long so in time I am sure they can iron out the kinks and try to match the food and service with their surroundings. I think that replying to less than positive reviews might be a good start.

review_preview: After reading the great reviews on TA, I was so excited to be visiting Flavia on our first night in Madrid. The Resturant itself is beautiful with great decor and a very stylish finish. However this is where unfortunately the happiness ends. The nice guy...
review_full: After reading the great reviews on TA, I was so excited to be visiting Flavia on our first night in Madrid. The Resturant itself is beautiful with great decor and a very stylish finish. However this is where unfortunately the happiness ends.  The nice guy on door was without doubt the only person in Resturant who knew how a Resturant should be run. The waitress who served our table was in a constant rush bearing in mind there were only 3 tables taken in the whole place! Absolutely no table service skills what so ever.  Starters were warm and far to salty. My husband lasagne looked nothing like the pictures on here at all.... It was so dry, like it had been reheated several times that day and cold in middle (which of course we sent back).  Whilst we were waiting for the bill we overheard the waitress asking a table near to us if they wanted a small drink on the house, not once did she offer us which we thought was rather rude and strange. I could seriously go on and on about this place. Such a shame as we were looking forward to it.  Overall we lasted 1 hour and 5 minutes in there, I should imagine people have taken longer to eat in fast food Restaurants and paid a lot less.  I would recommend going for drinks at bar first to see what you think.

review_preview: What a great environment, with nice music choices, and a really nice ambiance. The food was excellent; my mom, sister, and I all had three of the sauces and pastas – all delicious! We also tried the tiramisu, which came in a wine glass, not...
review_full: What a great environment, with nice music choices, and a really nice ambiance. The food was excellent; my mom, sister, and I all had three of the sauces and pastas – all delicious! We also tried the tiramisu, which came in a wine glass, not as a cake but more as a pudding, which was unexpected but really excellent as well! Our waiter was very friendly and conversational, and the staff recommended to us what to order, and inquired about our stay in Madrid and where we were from. At the end of the night, I really felt like part of the family, with the owner coming to say hello and pour us three shots on the house. All in all, what a perfect last meal in Madrid!

review_preview: This restaurant was recommended to us by the concierge at our hotel in Madrid. We briefly hesitated about having Italian food while we were in Spain, but then decided we might enjoy the change in cuisine. There were several  items on the menu which looked...
review_full: This restaurant was recommended to us by the concierge at our hotel in Madrid. We briefly hesitated about having Italian food while we were in Spain, but then decided we might enjoy the change in cuisine. There were several items on the menu which looked appealing, but the server (Daniel, who was excellent) suggested I try the lasagna, which he said was one of their specialties. So I chose that and it was delicious. My wife had the salmon. The portion was large and she said it was excellent. For dessert we had the tiramisu, which is served in something resembling a flower pot. A unique presentation, to be sure. It was very good as well. Our server Daniel, brought us each limoncello which finished off our meal perfectly. The meal was reasonably priced and I highly recommend this restaurant.

review_preview: We decided to visit this place for some pre-dinner drinks, based on the reviews, and we are so glad we did.The bar itself is like stepping back in time and offers an authentic insight into 'old' Madrid. We arrived about 9pm and found ourselves...
review_full: We decided to visit this place for some pre-dinner drinks, based on the reviews, and we are so glad we did. The bar itself is like stepping back in time and offers an authentic insight into 'old' Madrid. We arrived about 9pm and found ourselves a place at the bar (tables are available too).  Offering 5 types of sherry, we ended up staying rather longer than anticipated and sampled four of the five on offer. All were delicious, in their own right. Each glass was served with complimentary snacks (including the best olives), and you can order additional tapas-style small plates (meats, cheese, anchovies etc). Whilst not sufficient really for a whole meal (that's not the idea here) they were a delicious accompaniment to the sherry on offer. This place was an amazing experience and something I'd definitely recommend to get a real feel for Madrid and its history. It offers exceptional value, with each glass of sherry ranging between 1.90 - 2.20 euros, and most of the tapas dishes just a couple of euros each. Whilst sherry is the only drink on offer here so is obviously great for sherry lovers, it's also a great way for those who aren't as familiar with sherry to come and have a try - at only a couple of euros a glass it's an easy (and cheap) way to sample a selection. This was a fantastic way to end our final evening in Madrid and wish only that there were more treasures like this place!

review_preview: After sampling the tapas at Plaza Santa Ana, we went into a few bars looking without success for a selection of sherries for a night cap. One bartender said he didn't have any but he wrote the name and address of La Venencia on a...
review_full: After sampling the tapas at Plaza Santa Ana, we went into a few bars looking without success for a selection of sherries for a night cap. One bartender said he didn't have any but he wrote the name and address of La Venencia on a paper napkin and called it the best sherry bar in Madrid. It looks like a working man's bar from 100 years ago, with barrels of sherry behind the bar. The walls have faded sherry posters and there's an old phone that doesn't work on the wall. There are only a few tables and most customers stand at the bar and talk to each other. I asked for two sherries one level sweeter than the very dry "fino". The bartender said they don't use the term "mas dulce" but rather "menos seco." He brought us two glasses of palo cortado and a plate of olives. The bill was 4 Euros 40. I told him to keep the change and he said it was against the policy of the bar to accept tips, so he gave me 60 cents in change. If you like sherry in an authentic setting, go to La Venencia. If not, don't, as sherry is all they offer.

review_preview: This Italian restaurant is beautifully and elegantly decorated inside and has different zones with traditional tables and chairs and also tall stools (comfortable).The fare is typical for your standard Italian restaurant: basically pizza and pasta with some little extras. You can choose the type...
review_full: This Italian restaurant is beautifully and elegantly decorated inside and has different zones with traditional tables and chairs and also tall stools (comfortable). The fare is typical for your standard Italian restaurant: basically pizza and pasta with some little extras. You can choose the type of pasta you want and then choose the best sauce to go with it. All combinations are possible. The quality, however, was fairly mediocre (other similar restaurants offer better consistently better food - the "Tagliatelle" chain, for example). Burrata was quite nice, the tortellini con carne with Amatriciana sauce was ok. No sparks though. The service tries extremely hard but generally gives an impression of total chaos rather than efficiency (the waiters seemed to spend at least the duration of our meal running around breathlessly), and coordination between staff was clearly not a strong point. Price: for a shared Burrata and a pasta combo each (5 people), water (no wine) and one desert, we paid just over 30 euros each. Expensive. Not bad. But with so many better places around, why return?

review_preview: La Venencia is a hard place to describe.  It is not at all trendy but in some ways is very hip.  To my husband and I it is a must when in Madrid.  It is small and rather dusty and only serves various sherries and...
review_full: La Venencia is a hard place to describe. It is not at all trendy but in some ways is very hip. To my husband and I it is a must when in Madrid. It is small and rather dusty and only serves various sherries and a few simple tapas. It is an authentic watering hole in an age where everything seems to change and sometimes try too hard. Apparently Ernest Hemingway frequented La Venencia and it is easy to see why. I don't think that the decor has changed at all since he was last there. If you are a lover of tradition ( or good sherry) this is a very special place in the heart of old Madrid.

review_preview: My wife and I ate here twice during a 5 day period in Madrid in Oct 2015. We frequently try Italian cuisine in countries other than Italy and are never disappointed.   Here at Piccolo Diavolo - don't be put off by exterior appearance. The young...
review_full: My wife and I ate here twice during a 5 day period in Madrid in Oct 2015. We frequently try Italian cuisine in countries other than Italy and are never disappointed. Here at Piccolo Diavolo - don't be put off by exterior appearance. The young staff are immediately friendly and pleased to see you, and there's no shortage of attention throughout the meal. It's a small intimate place with no frills; nevertheless a bustling, pleasant atmosphere (plus music in the background). The menu is short but plenty of established favourites in the salad/pasta/carne categories; and when the food comes it is clear the kitchen knows its stuff (hence our second visit). We didn't try the pizzas, although we saw some excellent examples going to other tables. We ordered simple dishes, eg. A caprese salad and then a bolognese ragu were very satisfying, and just what was needed. The house wines are exceptionally good value in our view. So all in all we'd say excellent value indeed, in a friendly intimate atmosphere, and well worth a visit.

title_review: Friendly service and delicious food! One of the nicest restaurants in Madrid!
review_preview: The food was so good here. They have a wide range of pasta and sauces you can mix and match from, all at an affordable prize. They also have chicken and beef dishes and great pizza. We came in august and didn't even need a...
review_full: The food was so good here. They have a wide range of pasta and sauces you can mix and match from, all at an affordable prize. They also have chicken and beef dishes and great pizza. We came in august and didn't even need a reservation, It was very quite and we hardly had to wait 3 minutes to be served our food. Then after the meal we were offered free lemon liqueur shots on the house! It was amazing quality and the prefect way to end the night.  The food was prefect, I couldn't say any thing wrong about it. But the service was even better! We ate there here two times. The first time we were served by this really friendly man. He was funny and chatty and was super welcoming! After our meal we had a great chat with him about Ireland and he told us about a local parade that was going on. He was so nice! We came back two days later and were served by the same guy. he remembered us and we chatted with him some more. He always had a smile on his face! When we left the chef actually came out to talk to us. You could see he really cared about his restaurant and his customers.  And the inside of the restaurant was fabulous! It was cozy and relaxing with soft lighting and lots of flawless decorations. They had nice music playing, which wasn't really to my taste but my mother liked it. Still, it added to a great atmosphere.  This restaurant is perfect for a date or even for families! Its right beside the VP Jardin de Recoletos hotel, about a 1 minute walk from the National Archeological museum and It's about 8-10 minutes from the retiro park. If you plan to visit the retiro park or the Archeological museum then I highly recommend this restaurant!

title_review: Fun Little Italian Bistro that's delicious
review_preview: One of my favorite areas in Madrid is Recoletos. And there is nothing quite better than looping your way through the narrow streets off the Paseo de la Castellana/Paseo de Prado and having dinner in a Modern hip Italian/cocktail restaurant tucked a way between this...
review_full: One of my favorite areas in Madrid is Recoletos. And there is nothing quite better than looping your way through the narrow streets off the Paseo de la Castellana/Paseo de Prado and having dinner in a Modern hip Italian/cocktail restaurant tucked a way between this grand path and the posh Calle Serrano. Italian you say? In Madrid? Yes, absolutely. I had a party of 5 in tow, adults and children of different ages and tastes. The staff was extraordinarily accomodating especially the head waiter/manager. The Woodfired Pizzas and homemade pastas are extarordinarily authentic as they import much of their ingredients from Italy. We tried the Siciian with divine anchovies and the Margarita Pizzas and they were so tasty and the crust was perfectly cooked. Cutting the pizza at the table was also a nice touch. We orded the gnocchi and its a must have as its fresh and like all their tomato based dishes, addicting. The drinks were super as cocktails are their thing and they were truly generous in serving us a wonderful starter/amuse bouche at the beginning and grappa at the end of the night. I highly recommend this place as its delicious. While it may be a departure from Spanish food, Flavia is truly gorgeous, intimate and situated in a perfect location that makes you feel less like a tourist and more like Madrileno out for the night!

title_review: One of my favorite places on the planet

There are six sherries on tap and a few basic but excellent tapas to be had. Stand at the bar or sit at one of the small tables and imagine what Madrid was like during the ups and downs of its last 75 years.

title_review: One of the strangest restaurants I have visited.
review_preview: This place is old, have no music, no wine, no beer, no dishes and is absolutely fantastic. They serve Jerez and local tapas from the Jerez district in the south of Spain. With an intense atmosphere, plenty of people and a locale that is as...
review_full: This place is old, have no music, no wine, no beer, no dishes and is absolutely fantastic. They serve Jerez and local tapas from the Jerez district in the south of Spain. With an intense atmosphere, plenty of people and a locale that is as rustic as it gets this is really a place worth visiting. Not the place for dinner, and you get more of the vibe if you stand by the bar, but even seated you understand that this place is special.  So go there, have some jerez and tapas, and talk to people!

review_preview: We ended up here as it was just around the corner from our apartment. There was no one in the restaurant section and just a couple of people at the bar. They seemed a bit perplexed as to why we might be there but were...
review_full: We ended up here as it was just around the corner from our apartment. There was no one in the restaurant section and just a couple of people at the bar. They seemed a bit perplexed as to why we might be there but were pleasant and arranged us at a table soon enough. Food - we had the guacamole to share (excellent) and then both chose the squid ink pasta with seafood. Very good. Bread was excellent. Wine - the house wine was a good match for the food. The service - was a touch whimsical but fine on the whole. To explain - we were left alone to the point where we just starting to think we had been forgotten. And then the lady who ran front of house appeared. Explained the menu, took our order and then was spirited away. At another time we asked what was in a dish and next thing, the lady was back with her friend and her daughter to all help with the conversation. Pleasant, fun but occasionally disconcerting. Maybe why some other reviewers had a problem? Good value and enjoyable overall.

Our starters arrived at least twenty minutes apart from each other and one main course (the rib-eye steak) was not cooked to order. review_full: We booked a table at this lovely local Taberna for 9:30pm. The bar was packed and the table seating was also completely booked with local Spanish families/friends by 10pm. Our server was excellent, helping us choose dishes and giving great advice. We started with free plate of tiny sausages (yum). Ordered oro de patatas (great), ensaladilla rusa (ok, kind of like chicken salad), arroz ceta (delicious creamy rice and mushrooms), mejillones (perfectly spiced mussels), and lomo de carne (fabulous seared tenderloin that was like “buttah”). Too much food (our server tried to tell us that) but we wanted to try everything. So glad we did. House wine and bread for 75Euros for two people. Great value, wonderful atmosphere and very enjoyable evening.

title_review: A Monument to Spain's Turbulent Past
review_preview: It's a bit sad to see all these photos of La Venencia on this site as it is disrespectful to the bar. This bar was frequented by republican and socialist supporters during the Franco fascist regime. They would meet here in secret to discuss politics....
review_full: It's a bit sad to see all these photos of La Venencia on this site as it is disrespectful to the bar. This bar was frequented by republican and socialist supporters during the Franco fascist regime. They would meet here in secret to discuss politics. Franco's secret police would spy on them and take their photographs which led to dire consequences for the people involved. Hence why the proprietor requests customers not to take photos as a tribute to those customers back in those dark days who were spirited away by the fascist security services. Similarly, in tribute to republican socialism, the staff won't accept tips. Anyhow, the place? It's a fantastic place to visit for sherry and tapas. Manzanilla ice cold and delicious plump green olives. The bar staff chalk your bill on the counter in front of you, then you pay the final total when you leave. It's got a special community feel about it: locals frequent it but passing visitors are made to feel welcome.

There are other gourmet burger spots in Madrid, but this one is my favorite ever. The Colmenares Gang knew from the very begginin the success formula, quality, quality and quality. And this is what they have been doing since they opened. The menu runs under the KISS rule, Keep It Simple Stupid. I was here once more last week to taste my favorite, Harlem Burger, this time 350grs, I have eaten a couple of times 500grs, but you need to be really hungry to cope with this. On my second visit I ate pasta, which was boiled perfectly al dente, to taste with your teeth, not too soft.

title_review: Cozy Restaurant in Madrid's Theater District, on a little side street
review_preview: This small cozy restaurant was the perfect spot to meet up with some friends also travelling through Spain on our crossover days in Madrid.   It provided the perfect quaint atmosphere for us to share stories of our travels over dinner.  Each of us truly enjoyed...
review_full: This small cozy restaurant was the perfect spot to meet up with some friends also travelling through Spain on our crossover days in Madrid. It provided the perfect quaint atmosphere for us to share stories of our travels over dinner. Each of us truly enjoyed our meals and vino! We opted for no appetizers, so we went right for the entrees. I had the duck, it was perfectly prepared, no grease at all, atop of a bed of couscous and drizzled with a delicious raspberry sauce. My friends had the cod and the oxtail. We left the restaurant with 3 clean dishes. And on the way out everyone said good bye, even the friendly dog sitting in the bar area with his human. Overall, friendly service in a quaint atmosphere serving delicious, well plated meals.

review_preview: I found this restaurant on Eater's Essential 38 for Madrid, and had high expectations--they were exceeded in all respects. I reserved a table at 8 p.m., and we were promptly seated by the owner, who offered menus in English or Spanish. After reviewing the wine...
review_full: I found this restaurant on Eater's Essential 38 for Madrid, and had high expectations--they were exceeded in all respects. I reserved a table at 8 p.m., and we were promptly seated by the owner, who offered menus in English or Spanish. After reviewing the wine list, and finding nothing I was familiar with, I asked for his assistance selecting a wine. He asked the style of our preference and confirmed that we wished to try a Spanish wine. He said that the wine I would like most (at a modest 22 Euros) was not listed on the menu, and he proceeded to bring us a bottle of chardonnay that was exactly the style we prefer. We ordered a variety of things (more than we needed), including an excellent foie gras with caramelized apples, a tender artichoke heart presented in the shape of a flower, truffled potato croquettes, Tomatoes Raf (an heirloom tomato salad, with sweet onions), luxuriously creamy rice with shrimp, and my daughter loved the Wagyu hamburger. Each dish was exceptional, and for the quality and quantity, we considered it a very good value (total bill was approximately 100 Euros for 3). We were the only non-locals in the tables area of the restaurant, and found the bar packed with Spanish speakers on the way out at 10:30 p.m. on a Tuesday night. Our waitress was very helpful with suggestions, spoke English well, and secured a taxi for us when we were ready to leave. Reservations are essential; every table was occupied by 9 p.m.

review_preview: La Luna 22 is one of my favorite restaurants in Europe.  It's a great place to stop for lunch or dinner if you want to take a break from the bustle of the city center without having to leave it.The restaurant is owned by...
review_full: La Luna 22 is one of my favorite restaurants in Europe. It's a great place to stop for lunch or dinner if you want to take a break from the bustle of the city center without having to leave it. The restaurant is owned by the chef and the head waiter, and they and the lovely waitress truly treat their clients like guests. The service is genuinely warm and remarkably attentive (but without any hovering!). And the food is fantastic.  The appetizers are homemade and delicious (it is my goal to sample all of them!),  the main dishes are simple and perfectly prepared--always very fresh and delicious with some quite healthy options,  and the desserts are not to be missed! I am particularly addicted to the homemade flan they serve with the lunch menu! All this in a quiet, cozy setting, 2 minutes from the Gran Vía. I've recently discovered that they do breakfast too! Great coffee! And the prices are really reasonable -- 10.80 Euros for the 3-course lunch menu, beverage included.  My husband and I had dinner there last night -- three courses (we split the appetizer), a lovely bottle of wine, coffees and an after-dinner drink for 50-something euros. La Luna 22 is one of those gorgeous places that is worth going back to again and again because of the excellent food and wonderful service.  My favorite place to eat in Madrid!

review_preview: La Catapa is one of a growing number of very good tapas bars/restaurants in this area. A tour taking in a few of them will leave you wondering why you bother with any other barrio in the city - the general standard is that good....
review_full: La Catapa is one of a growing number of very good tapas bars/restaurants in this area. A tour taking in a few of them will leave you wondering why you bother with any other barrio in the city - the general standard is that good. It will also leave you wanting to walk off some of the excesses you are likely to indulge in, which makes its location next to the Retiro very convenient.  The food and wine here at La Catapa, as previous reviewers indicate, of a high standard. There is a creative streak running through the tapas menu, in a similar vein to its predecessor, Laredo. The wine list is excellent and you can enjoy a good Spanish wine for a very reasonable price. Service is very friendly and helpful.  Only one quibble - since taking over these premises from Taberna Laredo (must be a couple of years ago?), the owners have failed to really create a strong identity for La Catapa - the bar still looks as though Laredo has just moved out and these guys have moved in, plonking down some trays of food on the counters. It all lacks the panache and energy of Laredo, and fails to deliver the same sort of excitement. It's pleasant enough... just a little too anodyne for my taste. I think the place could use a vibrant, energetic barman or two and the owners should zing up its rather tired decor. Change the colour scheme and fill in some of the large spaces left behind the bar when Laredo moved on - just make it their own space. At the moment, everything says this is a temporary stop-over on the way to somewhere else. La Catapa isn't yet an essential stop when I'm in the area. It has a lot of very strong local competition and they need to do a bit more to match the buzz you experience when you visit some of their neighbours. But if you fancy a quiet evening, enjoying some great tapas and wine, served by people who care about your satisfaction, you could do a lot worse than to spend your money here.

title_review: Great Food, Wine and Service - A "Must Go To" Retiro Restaurant
review_preview: This bar and restaurant is situated in a quiet residential area of the city close to Retiro Park. We are staying for two months in an apartment overlooking the park and Taberna La Catapa has become our favourite place both for a glass of wine...
review_full: This bar and restaurant is situated in a quiet residential area of the city close to Retiro Park. We are staying for two months in an apartment overlooking the park and Taberna La Catapa has become our favourite place both for a glass of wine and tapas in the bar and for dinner in the restaurant. The menu is varied and interesting, and every dish we have had has been well cooked and very nicely presented. The wine list has good Spanish wines to suit most tastes and pockets. Most importantly the service is welcoming and friendly yet professional. The staff go out of their way to ensure that you enjoy your time with them. This is not an inexpensive restaurant but we always come away feeling that we have had excellent value for money. We shall be in Madrid for another six weeks and will almost certainly go to Taberna La Catapa about two times a week!

This area is filled with amazing tapas restaurants, I'd recommend you have one tapa (and of course, a glass of wine) on each one of them. A nice route is Taberna La Catapa, Taberna Laredo and Arzábal (all at a walking distance from each other)

review_preview: I very much enjoyed ¨Catapa¨. I am the chef-owner of the Barcelona Tapas in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico. I have no previous relationship with the chef or owner of this restaurant. I normal do not right review but I feel that this one deserves it.  I...
review_full: I very much enjoyed ¨Catapa¨. I am the chef-owner of the Barcelona Tapas in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico. I have no previous relationship with the chef or owner of this restaurant. I normal do not right review but I feel that this one deserves it. I recommend that you try this off the non tourist restaurant for true local flavor by an experienced hard working young local chef. I was very fortunate to have found this place due to a wine sales woman that I met while shopping. Since she is from Madrid and sells wines to many restaurants she turned me on to ¨Catapa¨. We drank a very smooth well rounded wine called Pujanza 2008 for 25 euros and a great value for a reasonable price. We ordered two kinds of ¨croquetas¨ which are fried, one made with cured spanish ham and the other with natural truffle. Both are top notch but my favorite were the truffle croquetas. The salads were wonderful and I repeated the quail salad twice. The bread was very interesting which was a combination of a country style bread and rye mixed together and very tasty. They offer local fresh tapas of seafood and beef which were top quality and large portions. We an aged ¨chuleton¨which is aged beef bone on ribeye of the highes quality and was big enough for 3 people. It was 68 euros but worth the price for the quality and preparation. I would like to go back to this place and try all the dishes. I have been studying Spanish cuisine since 1987 and this place is a down to earth restaurant tapas bar which I believe is well worth the trip. As to speak to the chef whom is very knowledgeable and friendly.

title_review: Great Food and Service in an Authentic Tapas Bar full of locals
review_preview: Close to the Retiro park the Catapa is for me the best tapa's bar in town. Not only because of its excellent food and great choice of wine, but also because of  Miguel Angel and his team who celebrate Spanish hospitality at his best. The...
review_full: Close to the Retiro park the Catapa is for me the best tapa's bar in town. Not only because of its excellent food and great choice of wine, but also because of Miguel Angel and his team who celebrate Spanish hospitality at his best. The must of the place: Tortilla, Croquetas (with truffel) and the Tartar. A part from that, try the Morcilla (blood pudding), you won't find it better in Madrid and the Berberchos, which you won't find bigger in town. And follow the recommendation of the daily dishes. You can't fail. And the aperitivos (small dishes you receive for free with every drink you order) are generous and varied.

The restaurant remained pretty quiet on this Tuesday evening - the next punters arriving only as we were receiving coffee. Well priced and worth considering if you're looking for a quiet evening away from the tourist crowds.

review_preview: When we travel, three things are important: site-seeing, interacting with the local people and their culture, and of course, enjoying traditional cuisine.  This review focuses on the cuisine.We are “foodies” and enjoy the total experience of great food, presentation and service.  While recently in...
review_full: When we travel, three things are important: site-seeing, interacting with the local people and their culture, and of course, enjoying traditional cuisine. This review focuses on the cuisine. We are “foodies” and enjoy the total experience of great food, presentation and service. While recently in Madrid, we made our way to Taberna Laredo. Unfortunately, without reservations, we were out of luck; it was full. As tourists we didn’t know the neighborhood, so we asked the waiter for a recommendation. His recommendation was right across the street, called Taberna La Catapa. We had a lovely evening and dining experience. The menu was only in Spanish, so the chef-owner came to our table and discussed the entire menu with us. He made recommendations, and having just come from Barcelona, we decided to think out-of-the box and try new things. The dishes were fabulous, and the presentations were excellent. My husband went for the razor clams, in season and he loved them. I had the oxtail stew; it was marvelous just like great comfort food should be. Our cousin had what the chef called his grandma’s recipe, which was rice with squid in black ink. The dish was one of the best I have ever tasted. The white rice was placed on the plate as a round mold surrounded by thick black ink with the squid – it was awesome! Words can’t express how delicious this dish was. The owner came after dinner to talk with us, and we learned the restaurant just opened six months ago and it’s his first. It is very small, but lovely: a small tapas bar upstairs and a few tables downstairs, all contemporary and harmonious. When in Madrid, we will definitely come here again. The experience was wonderful and contributed to our experience of a lovely stay in Spain. If in Madrid, go here for a warm, lovely and delicious meal. Taberna La Catapa, located on Calle Menorca, 19 Madrid. Telephone number 686.14.38.23. The owner is Miguel Angel Jimenez Garcia, a lovely person.  Thank you, Miguel, and your staff for such a memorable meal.

review_preview: We have been to this small, local neighborhood bar, popular for its tapas, perfectly tapped Mahou, and its rather extensive wine list by the glass.The atmosphere is very friendly, but definitely a bit posh and geared towards the upper class folks that reside in...
review_full: We have been to this small, local neighborhood bar, popular for its tapas, perfectly tapped Mahou, and its rather extensive wine list by the glass. The atmosphere is very friendly, but definitely a bit posh and geared towards the upper class folks that reside in and around the neighborhood. Nevertheless, don't let that deter you from stopping in for a couple of rounds. The waiters are professional and very friendly despite the fact that both times we arrived at around 1:30 in the afternoon the bar was packed, so I would recommend that you get there early if you want your little slice of the bar. Another place not far away I would highly recommend is El Capricho.

review_preview: We ate at Taberna La Catapa twice in July. We did not have a reservation the first night, but we were warmly welcomed and a table was found after we had an enjoyed a glass of wine at the busy bar.  Both nights we were...
review_full: We ate at Taberna La Catapa twice in July. We did not have a reservation the first night, but we were warmly welcomed and a table was found after we had an enjoyed a glass of wine at the busy bar. Both nights we were given a small tapa to share--a delicious eggplant the first night and an olive dish the second night. Each course was freshly made and brought to our table as it is prepared in the kitchen. They prepare the burrata, tomato and arugula salad at the table, which was my personal favorite. My 10 year old daughter ate the hamburger entree twice...not an ordinary hamburger...but one prepared with sauteed onions, cheese, pesto, on an incredibly delicious bread. Our seafood was fresh and the cheese plate spectacular. You can purchase wines by the bottle or glass, and they also have beer. This is a wonderful restaurant near the Retiro Park in a residential area. I look forward to eating here when we return to Madrid. Thank you to the chef and owner, Miguel Angel Jimenez Garcia, and his fantastic staff.

Then he walked us through the entire menu, as it was only in Spanish. We had the croquettes with truffles--outstanding--,grilled artichokes with jamon iberico and razor clams. Wonderful all of it. Two desserts and a bottle of wine, $74 euro, a bargain for such high quality food. The service and the pacing were terrific. Not much English spoken the night we were there--mostly the chef--but it didn't matter. Highly recommended.

review_preview: This was our favorite restaurant in Madrid. It is a neighborhood spot filled with locals and the owner is very welcoming, very friendly. They do speak English which is a major plus since my Spanish is pretty poor. Most importantly, the food was terrific and...
review_full: This was our favorite restaurant in Madrid. It is a neighborhood spot filled with locals and the owner is very welcoming, very friendly. They do speak English which is a major plus since my Spanish is pretty poor. Most importantly, the food was terrific and there is a very good wine selection by the glass and by the bottle. We asked them to match glasses of wine to individual dishes and they were spot on. They answered all our questions and made suggestions regarding regional specialities. My son has a nut allergy and they totally understood and worked with us. I would strongly recommend it. When I think of Madrid, this is the first place that comes to mind.

review_preview: Since our first review in July 2013, we have eaten here on a number of occasions - sometimes dropping in for a glass of wine and some tapas and sometimes dining in the restaurant. We have thoroughly enjoyed every occasion.We find the menu and...
review_full: Since our first review in July 2013, we have eaten here on a number of occasions - sometimes dropping in for a glass of wine and some tapas and sometimes dining in the restaurant. We have thoroughly enjoyed every occasion. We find the menu and the "daily specials" varied and interesting, the wine list seems to us to offer a range of wines likely to suit most tastes and pockets and the service is welcoming, friendly and professional.  We feel that the chef/proprietor takes a real pride in the quality of produce used, the manner in which it is cooked and the way it is presented. Taberna La Catapa is not a cheap restaurant but to us it is not expensive for what it offers - we always come away pleased that we have received value for money.  We would recommend Taberna La Catapa to anyone looking to enjoy good food, wine and service in the Retiro Park area. We shall certainly eat there again: in fact we shall be in Madrid in June and have made a booking for then.

title_review: Continues to Offer Great Food and First Class Service

review_full: We visit Madrid on business several times a year and Taberna La Catapa is high on our list of restaurants. It is located in the Ibiza area of Retiro (a few minutes walk from the park) - a short taxi ride from the centre of Madrid and well worth the trip.You can eat in the bar area (from a varied tapas menu) or the adjoining restaurant area. My wife and I had dinner there recently in the restaurant and, as we always do, enjoyed every dish. The quality of the produce used, the cooking and the presentation are, in our view, excellent. The chef/proprietor takes a real pride in his business and focuses on giving his clients good food, professionally served in a comfortable ambience. A good sign for us is that each time we are there, the majority of clients are regulars who live in Retiro.

review_full: We were blown away- this is our 10th trip to Madrid. Why did it take us so long to find La Catapa?! We loved the red curry mussels and salmorejo most of all - but honestly, it was all fabulous. Our server was the most wonderful person- she guided us through the wine and food menus with such charm - and what good advice!  We sat at a table off to the left inside the restaurant, rather than the bar, and we were glad that we did- it was a simple but lovely setting. It was romantic without being over the top- cozy and delightful! And oh, the food, the food! Words do not do it justice. The seafood is excellent and the curry was beyond description- better than any curry I have had anywhere else in the world! I could not believe it! It was a bit spicy, but not too hot. Don't be afraid to try something you've never had before here. The tried and true tapas menu will not disappoint, but the other items on the menu will amaze you. I only wish I'd found this place sooner and that my stomach would agree to let me eat just a little more- oh what a treat! We are going back tomorrow!

review_full: During our city trip to Madrid, we wanted to try something authentic, outside the tourist area. Thanks to Maribel's Guide (you find her website if you type "Maribel's guide" on google) we have ended in this restaurant full with locals. At 10:30 in the evening, the restaurant was full and it was only thanks to the friendly and helpful waiters that managed to get 2 places at the bar. As our Spanish was far from perfect we have asked for some advise for choosing the food. It was the chef in person that came and explained what are the house specialities. We have appreciated the fact that he was really not looking to trick us into ordering the most expensive things on the menu, but really the best things. We were spoiled with truffle croquettes, mini beef hamburgers, baby calamari, anchovies... They had very good wine too. It is definitely one of the best places I have ever eaten. Make sure that you do not miss this hidden gem while in Madrid :)

title_review: Nice Evening. Food OK. Friendly Service.
review_preview: We enjoyed our evening at Taberna La Catapa. The restaurant is apparently quite popular as it messaged me to confirm our booking on the day. It is located on a quiet side street and is about 5 mins walk from the Ibiza metro station in...
review_full: We enjoyed our evening at Taberna La Catapa. The restaurant is apparently quite popular as it messaged me to confirm our booking on the day. It is located on a quiet side street and is about 5 mins walk from the Ibiza metro station in a safe neighbourhood. On a Tuesday evening the tapas bar in the front of the restaurant was lively, and the dining room at the back was full. Reservation is necessary. Decor of the dining area is simple. There were only a few tables, No English menus. The serving ladies were friendly but did not speak much English, but the gentleman from the tapas bar came and helped us out with the menu. Very kind. Food was not bad. We had octopus salad and razor clams as appetisers, pork and seafood omelette for main course. Dinner for the two of us cost Euro 70 including one cocktail. I think diners probably have more fun at the tapas bar, and some knowledge of Spanish would definitely enhance the dining experience.

title_review: Small Restaurant, Intimate Dining, Good Food
review_preview: I had the fideula (a Catalan twist on paella, made with noodles instead of rice) with duck and mushrooms. It was tasty, though I saw many more mushrooms than duck, and the sauce had a similar flavor to teriyaki, but it was a pleasant dish,...
review_full: I had the fideula (a Catalan twist on paella, made with noodles instead of rice) with duck and mushrooms. It was tasty, though I saw many more mushrooms than duck, and the sauce had a similar flavor to teriyaki, but it was a pleasant dish, and more food than I could finish in a sitting, though I tried! The ambiance here is great. Wait staff was attentive and helpful (taught me how to pronounce fideula -- if you're curious, the accent is on the last syllable: "fih-day-oo-LA", not "fih-DAY-oo-la"; it's alternately spelled fideuá.) Would come back for sure.

title_review: Awesome local dishes great customer service
review_preview: Very awesome experience here. I highly recommend making reservations here because there aren't too many tables available and a ton of people are standing to eat and drink wine there for hours because it is such a great place. All the food I had was...
review_full: Very awesome experience here. I highly recommend making reservations here because there aren't too many tables available and a ton of people are standing to eat and drink wine there for hours because it is such a great place. All the food I had was great, fresh, and executed well.  The customer service was very good. There were two female waitresses who served me and they were fantastic. One thing my boss taught me and others to have at our workplace is something called a "can do attitude." That means that even though something is difficult we don't say "oh no we can't do that. Oh that's against the rules." Instead we say "Yes we can do it. let us find a way to accomplish this" This mentality of a can do attitude is exactly what the waitresses have here. This place is not a tourist trap and serves mostly the locals. Therefore the menu is in all Spanish and the waitresses don't speak much English. However, they worked very hard to communicate with me and try to get me exactly what I wanted. They checked on us throughout the entire evening even though everyone in that restaurant was stuffed in there like sardines. They were extremely polite and made sure we got everything we needed to be comfortable. I was very tired from a long day of walking and even though I didn't make reservations and therefore couldn't sit at one of the chairs, the waitress noticed I was tired and tried her best to tell me that I can sit there because the next reservation isn't a full party so they won't be needing it. I really appreciated that because my back was hurting and my feet were aching. Tip: Make reservations ahead of time. Ask your hotel to speak with them in spanish to do so. Use google translate to translate the menu (you can select the camera function to view the menu in real time and it translates it while you are hovering your phone over the menu). Also eat the truffle croquettes they are the best! I applaud this place for great local dishes and fantastic customer service.

review_preview: I had a reservation for 4 people to have dinner.  We were promptly on time, and started what we thought would be a great dinner.  The food was "ok", but the service was completely disrespectful! The servers were extremely rude, rolling their eyes when we...
review_full: I had a reservation for 4 people to have dinner. We were promptly on time, and started what we thought would be a great dinner. The food was "ok", but the service was completely disrespectful! The servers were extremely rude, rolling their eyes when we asked for more water.. etc. After dinner we ordered some pie, and chocolate cake.. we hadn't even finished the cake when the server/manager/rude employee came over and asked us to leave so they could have the table for people who were waiting for dinner.  First of all, we had a reservation....  Second - We has aprox. 2 glasses of wine left in the wine bottle, AND half a chocolate cake left to consume.  Third - I will NEVER return to this restaurant!  I have never been treated this way in Spain, and I've lived here for more than 4 years. We were completely floored that they would tell us... "I'm sorry, but we need to ask you to leave so we can have this table, we have people waiting" when we still had wine and food on the table that we were eating! There were other tables that had been there longer and yet they were not asked to leave.  Go at your own risk.. just make sure you eat very very fast, and drink that wine in one big gulp... or you too may be asked to leave before you're finished with your meal!

title_review: One of the best burgers in Madrid
review_preview: Problaby New York Burger has one of the best burgers in all Madrid. If you are a burguer lover you definitely have to go. New York Burguer has two shifts for dinner, so I recommend you to book before going. The local is spacious and...
review_full: Problaby New York Burger has one of the best burgers in all Madrid. If you are a burguer lover you definitely have to go. New York Burguer has two shifts for dinner, so I recommend you to book before going. The local is spacious and informal. But of course, the best of the restaurant are the Burgers cooked at the grill. The meat is very juicy and tender, with portions from 160 to 500 grames. The range of burgers is wide with some delicious combinations and creative names. The price of the burger of 350 grames is 12€, which is reasonable in comparation with the quality. For dessert we ordered a brownie which it doesn´t pay.

review_preview: We had lunch at New York Burger at Calle General Yague 5 (there's another one in the Recoletos area) after making an online reservation on their super efficient system (you receive both a confirmation text message and email). You can choose different sizes for your...
review_full: We had lunch at New York Burger at Calle General Yague 5 (there's another one in the Recoletos area) after making an online reservation on their super efficient system (you receive both a confirmation text message and email). You can choose different sizes for your burger (160 gr, 250 gr, 350 gr, and the only-for-some 500 gr). Regardless of the ingredients or side orders you choose, price depends only from the size of the burger, ranging from 7 to 15€ aprox. The meat was absolutely delicious and cooked precisely as we have ordered. The restaurant has a nice american feel, on the down side I'd only point out the fact that most of the tables are on the basement level, which is a bit too isolated for my taste, and that they do not serve coffee or tea. I found that a bit surprising! I noticed that they are very attentive with families with children: they provide some colour pencils and paper games, keeping them entertained and quiet, which makes everyone happy. A meal for 2 (2 burgers of 160 and 350 gr, 2 sparkling waters and a glass of whine) costed us 26€. Would recommend making a reservation beforehand!

title_review: Delicious Asian Fusion Tapas Bar Close to the Airport - open on Sundays
review_preview: Absolutely yum!  We wanted to end our trip to Spain on a high culinary note.  We succeeded.  We did not want to stray far from our convenient night-prior-to-departure Madrid airport hotel.  The eight euro taxi ride to Derzu Bar's nice little neighborhood was well worth...
review_full: Absolutely yum! We wanted to end our trip to Spain on a high culinary note. We succeeded. We did not want to stray far from our convenient night-prior-to-departure Madrid airport hotel. The eight euro taxi ride to Derzu Bar's nice little neighborhood was well worth it. The tapas, which were fresh and delicious riffs on different types of Asian dishes. We noted Korean, Thai, Vietnamese, and Japanese tastes. (We're from NY, near Queens which is an Asian foodie heaven) It was Mother's Day in Spain and Derzu was hopping with local families. A delicious, hip, casual spot for a light dinner and drinks. Call ahead, and on holidays, definitely make reservations. Open on Sundays!

review_preview: This new locale from the wonderful folks who run Bahía Tabera is located right around the corner in Barajas, Madrid.  The location is very inviting as the vibe is very laid back and cozy.  DerzuBar  manages to encapsulate everything I want in a restaurant: exquisite...
review_full: This new locale from the wonderful folks who run Bahía Tabera is located right around the corner in Barajas, Madrid. The location is very inviting as the vibe is very laid back and cozy. DerzuBar manages to encapsulate everything I want in a restaurant: exquisite quality of ingredients, bold innovative and scrumptious recipes presented artfully with zero arrogance/pretension. Reservations are recommended as this dining area is small but doesn't feel cramped. The magicians in the kitchen have nothing hidden up their sleeves as the masterpieces that arrive to your plate and palate are prepared right before your eyes. Eat here (and at Bahía Tabera) before the folks at Michelin find out so you can say you were a regular before they received their first star.

Don't be put off if the place isn't full and busy -- it filled up while we sat.

review_preview: I am a big fan of real burgers (hate fast food ones) and I've been trying several burger places in the city i live, Madrid. New York Burger is, so far, the best! everything was perfect! The staff was really nice, the place as nice,...

The staff was really nice, the place as nice, although a little bit noisy for me (but hey, if you are in Spain it is always like that) and the most important, of course, the food! I tried the chicken wings with the spicy sauce (so tender and tasty) the fries were just the way i like them, crispy, with skin and gold! The burger... The perfect burger! you can pick between different kinds of bread, side dish, grams of meet and how much you want it cook. And I can promise you that everything, the meet, the ingredients were just perfect!

review_preview: The restaurant is quite different from the fast food burger outlets, even to those where the client is seated. Yes, you're seated but the ambient is different; it makes you wait for good food. There are no memorabilia of musicians nor actors, nor a worn...
review_full: The restaurant is quite different from the fast food burger outlets, even to those where the client is seated. Yes, you're seated but the ambient is different; it makes you wait for good food. There are no memorabilia of musicians nor actors, nor a worn 50's look. Representing modern New York? (Can't say, never been to New York) :-) There is a risk that you get seated in the basement, but that should not be a showstopper. The basement has the same deco as the street level. Ambient is nice and calm, the service nice and courteous. One will have to wait for being seated, and will have to wait a little to get served, and a little to get the food. This is not about fast food, but not slow food either.  The menu of burgers is long enough, and quite creative. The client has to make selections. The size of the beef patty (160-500g), type of bread (or leave it out), potatoes or coleslaw... But wow, the burgers and fries are great! The price is of course more than in McD, but it is at the level of a lunch menu in Madrid. The General Yague and Recoletos of the New York Burger restaurants are equally good, I have visited both, and will go again. Hard Rock Cafe sells better shirts, though.

title_review: Incredible visit for sherry and history
review_preview: One of the highlights of our time in Madrid - a unique place full of history and wonderful sherry. The staff are friendly and attentive. I didn't find anywhere else in Madrid quite like it - shabby but incredibly charming. A sign indicates that patrons...
review_full: One of the highlights of our time in Madrid - a unique place full of history and wonderful sherry. The staff are friendly and attentive. I didn't find anywhere else in Madrid quite like it - shabby but incredibly charming. A sign indicates that patrons shouldn't take photos, making for an even more enjoyable visit in our instagram-craycray-era, but the rule actually originates from the 1930s and was put in place to protect Republicans from being incriminated by possible Fascist spies during the war. There were only locals in the bar with us - most people came in alone and were clearly regulars - all very welcoming and friendly though. The staff weren't sure how we'd found out about the place - I explained that I love sherry and enjoy it in a number of places in London, most of which he knew of and had visited in a previous trip to the city. There is a small tapas menu - perfect with the delicious drinks but not enough for your main meal of the day. Cheese and cured meats, etc. (NB I didn't like the dried tuna/fish roe, but locals seemed to be really keen) Tabs are written onto the wooden bar top with chalk, to be totted up when you want to leave (don't expect that to be any time soon - you'll love it too much). Tips aren't accepted - they will gracefully return them to you when you try to leave them! This rule also originates from it's Republican-sympathising roots. Wonderful place. Yummy Manzanilla.

review_preview: This place is a throwback to a bygone era or place ....the ubiquitous old sherry posters and wood, the dim lighting ...the emphasis on sherry (only sherry and water with some tapas) and certain "rules" of decorum (1) no photos and (2) no tipping (I...
review_full: This place is a throwback to a bygone era or place ....the ubiquitous old sherry posters and wood, the dim lighting ...the emphasis on sherry (only sherry and water with some tapas) and certain "rules" of decorum (1) no photos and (2) no tipping (I tried to tip and the owner politely told me they have tradition of not taking tips etc.) Yes this place may not appeal to everyone and yes the owner may appear dour and not "service happy" like in the USA but therein lies the problem with people's perception of service ..:friendliness does not equate with great service or attentiveness; the staff is attentive but not overly effusive with smiling bartenders etc. They all have restraint and that isn't a bad thing.  We ordered a couple of different sherrys and some tapas (chorizo and cheese) and they then proceed to pour us some wonderful sherry, the owner then approached the wooden bar counter and scribbled the tab with chalk (a la el rinconcillo en Sevilla).  We loved this place and you will too u just have to know what it is and what it isn't and what to expect.

review_preview: We started with the homemade burrata and it was wonderful.  Served with fresh, hot bread and cherry tomatoes.  Next I had the best duck breast I've ever eaten.  Perfectly seared and cooked served with an array of fried potatoes.  My wife had the fresh pear...

The desserts were both freshly made and delicious. This is a hidden gem away from the touristy area and truly the best meal during our 17 day tour of Europe.

review_preview: Flavia is in a charming, residential-and-shopping area of Barrio Salamanca. We arrived around 9 on a Saturday night with no restaurant and they were able to work us in. (Small party.) The food was very good, the service was friendly and attentive. Some other reviewers...

The food was very good, the service was friendly and attentive. Some other reviewers suggest that the prices may be a big high for Madrid, but we paid about half of what we would have paid in New York City for a comparable experience. The experience was marred only by a rosebud-seller who went from table to table, seemingly with management's approval, based on how I saw the personnel greet him. He was needlessly aggressive and persistent, and I had to ask the waiter to intervene. I debated between four and five for this reason, and have decided to let the five stand on the basis of food, atmosphere, and waitstaff -- with a warning about the rose guy.

title_review: Oh my Pasta, Sangria and Pizza!!
review_preview: Upon entering the restaurant you are greeted by a robust smoky mesquite smell that makes the appetite immediately. A meat slicer was present with a delicious piece of ham attached. Once greeted and seated at our table, an appetizer tray of this freshly sliced mortadella...

We ordered a fresh caprese salad, penne with a mushroom cream sauce, ziti and meat sauce and the four cheese pizza.  OUTSTANDING on all items.  Tastes that are well worth more money then charged.  Highly recommend and would visit again when visiting Madrid.

The food was so good! At the end, they offered a digestive on the house, which is always a nice touch. We also had a lovely bottle of wine. Great evening, and might even go back!

review_preview: Visited La Venencia 3 times in 4 days, so it must be doing something right. Perfect for a  pre-meal sherry, but pretty good after a meal as well! The owner and staff were not effusively welcoming, but it's not that type of place. We found...
review_full: Visited La Venencia 3 times in 4 days, so it must be doing something right. Perfect for a pre-meal sherry, but pretty good after a meal as well! The owner and staff were not effusively welcoming, but it's not that type of place. We found them to be reserved but perfectly pleasant. The sherry was great, and we sampled all 5 types during our visits. 1.90 euros per substantial glass, or you can buy a bottle or half bottle. No other drinks served apart from water. A mix of locals and tourists. Incredibly atmospheric, and a real step back in time. The equivalent English pub would be something like the Hare and Hounds in Shudehill, Manchester. If you want to experience authentic local life, rather than a characterless glitzy bar which you can see in any city, these are the places to go. Oh, and we finally saw the famous black cat on our last visit, curled up on a chair on the upper level....purrfecto!

title_review: Very good choice for italian food
review_preview: A group of 10 friends booked a table for a Xmas celebration last week, I didn't know the place but I was very pleased from the beginning. The staff is friendly (at least one girl was Italian), appetizers are 100% Italian (oh, that Mortadelia!), and...
review_full: A group of 10 friends booked a table for a Xmas celebration last week, I didn't know the place but I was very pleased from the beginning. The staff is friendly (at least one girl was Italian), appetizers are 100% Italian (oh, that Mortadelia!), and the food is good. Waiting time is average, Thin home-made pizzas y good quality pasta, everything was tasty and I would not mind going there again soon. We ate at the lower floor, there is an upper floor with a bar that is perfect for Italian Coffee or after-lunch drinks (good selection of fine brands). The restroom was the cleanest I have seen in years.  I would just point out 2 negative points: the seats on the lower floor might be comfortable or not, not all the chairs are the same, I saw flat wooden chairs and on the other side, ultra-cool armchairs. I took one of those and it was heaven! :) Also, the ambience music that is chosen is weird, I could hear twice the CD "Bossa and Stones", an awful selection of talentless whispered vocals on soft arrangements of Rolling Stones' classic tracks, so I guess the CD was on "repeat" mode. Trying to look cool and trendy? That wasn't working. The gorgeous 50s and 60s actresses posters displayed on the walls and the tasty food are clearly suggesting both something that is European and music from that era. There is plenty of music I can think of that would have been better. Sorry for that, but I can't give you the 5th star. Don' like my review and want to avoid criticism about music? Just don't have any music during lunch :)

If I’m ever back in Madrid this one restaurant I’m definitely going back to!!

title_review: More Argentinian than Maradona dancing tango... incredible meat too.
review_preview: From the Maradona goal against England in the 1986 World Cup playing on a tiny screen on a loop in the bathroom to the endless posters for Carlos Gardel, tango in general, and all things Argentino on the walls, the Viejo Almacén de Buenos Aires...
review_full: From the Maradona goal against England in the 1986 World Cup playing on a tiny screen on a loop in the bathroom to the endless posters for Carlos Gardel, tango in general, and all things Argentino on the walls, the Viejo Almacén de Buenos Aires wears its nationality broadly on its sleeve, and that´s fine by me. From a lack lustre location they have somehow created a restaurant that feels authentic and rooted. One of the waiters told me that they have been going for 41 years and 11 at the current location - and the pedigree shows. If you are looking for more elegant “Argentinian inspired” dining then this is not for you, but if you want small wine glasses, checkered table cloths and a traditional menu then look no further.  The fact that my entraña - a reference cut for me and one that I regularly eat was as good as I have ever had puts El Viejo Almacén de Buenos Aires at the top of my Argentinian in Madrid list. The burrata starter was also incredibly creamy and excellent.  My first visit was a work lunch, I can´t wait to go back for a private dinner and stay long into the night discussing old Boca-River duels with the waiters.

It has a graciously ageing decor and perfect dark wood furniture. To tell you anymore would spoil the surprise. Oh and don't break these house rules 1. No photos 2. No tipping

title_review: If you are not a Spaniard, maybe you should read this.
review_preview: Maybe you have read in Tripadvisor or in your preferred travel guide that this is a place to visit. And, as it is under “restaurants” label, you are thinking to drop you here for lunch or dinner.WRONG!La Venencia isn’t a restaurant. It’s a...
review_full: Maybe you have read in Tripadvisor or in your preferred travel guide that this is a place to visit. And, as it is under “restaurants” label, you are thinking to drop you here for lunch or dinner. WRONG! La Venencia isn’t a restaurant. It’s a place to drink wine. WRONG! La Venencia isn’t a place to drink wine. It’s a place to drink Sherry wines. Don’t ask for a bier, a coke or even a rioja wine. Ask for a manzanilla, ask for a palo cortao or ask for an amontillado or even an oloroso. And ask for any of the few tapas, but remember, they are offered only as a way to avoid getting drunk too soon! And enjoy it peacefully, while you are trying to guess when it was the last time the walls where painted, when was the last time the old bottles were dusted.  And enjoy having a wonderful wine in a place that hasn’t changed by decades, a place that is as it was, a preserved place of other ages. And my last (and maybe better) advice: take some minutes before your visit reading on the Wikipedia about what a “venencia” is - don't mix up venencia with Venecia - and about “Sherry” wines. Warning: Remember, pictures are not welcome at all.

We were so stuffed that we could not eat any dessert. Cesar. Thanks so much for making our last nite meal in Madrid so enjoyable and memorable. Till the next time we comeback here!

review_preview: After a month and a half of traveling in Spain and generally eating fabulous food, I suggest you skip this restaurant. Reservation was made via website, arrived on time, (Canadian), and waited for the host to seat us while he chatted to friends at the...
review_full: After a month and a half of traveling in Spain and generally eating fabulous food, I suggest you skip this restaurant. Reservation was made via website, arrived on time, (Canadian), and waited for the host to seat us while he chatted to friends at the bar. Finally seated and again waited for service. When it arrived, it was professional from then on.  Mortadella (amuse bouche) was delicious. Ensalada Caprese was horrible. It consisted of one leaf of basil, almost green tomatoes yet delicious mozzarella. Mains were Ravioletti Ricotta bufala e Spinaci Cream Tartufo e Funghi which was average and Pallarde alla Torinese which was a large “elephant ear sized breaded veal cutlet “as described by the server, served with fries. Not fond of garlic on my fries. Cutlet could feed four.  Ice cream was good. Might be great for pizza.

review_preview: We came back here a couple times during my visit to Madrid.  The restaurant offers a variety of pastas, including fresh pasta and stuffed pastas (ravioli).  I highly recommend the fresh pasta.  We tried a couple of sauces -- the bolognese and the arrabbiata were...
review_full: We came back here a couple times during my visit to Madrid. The restaurant offers a variety of pastas, including fresh pasta and stuffed pastas (ravioli). I highly recommend the fresh pasta. We tried a couple of sauces -- the bolognese and the arrabbiata were both good. I had the lasagna one time and thought that was the least good of what I had -- the flavor was good, but the texture was rather mushy. I'd suggest getting the fresh pasta or stuffed pastas. We also had one of the salads, which was delicious -- it came with a thick, sweet balsamic vinegar on top. Much better than your typical balsamic vinegar. Service was also very friendly!

title_review: This is great. Drink sherry, be happy.
review_preview: Don't be put off by the inauspicious surroundings and external appearances. This is real Madrid. The interior is brown, crumbling and in need of tlc but the atmosphere is great. They sell five types of sherry ranging from manzanilla to oloroso in glasses, half-bottles and...
review_full: Don't be put off by the inauspicious surroundings and external appearances. This is real Madrid. The interior is brown, crumbling and in need of tlc but the atmosphere is great. They sell five types of sherry ranging from manzanilla to oloroso in glasses, half-bottles and bottles. It is not expensive. They offer a limited range of tapas, half raciones and raciones; mainly plates of various meats and cheeses. Your bill is chalked up on the bar or table, and erased once you've paid. It is full of locals, many of whom look like real characters. However even as tourists we felt very comfortable and not in the least out of place. This is really worth a visit. Don't expect to sit down!

review_full: You would have to be an old male New Yorker to remember McSorley's Pub on East 3rd Street in Manhattan. Before the 70's only men were allowed in and it was before it lost its flavor. La Venencia has held on to it's Bohemian roots (no pictures are allowed) from the old days of early Franco. The bottles have not been dusted, nor the walls painted in this time warped bar. A nice place to stop for Mojama and a glass of sherry. I was told this was one of Hemmingway's favorite places.

title_review: Average to poor food and terrible service
review_preview: We were recommended this restaurant by someone who had been here previously. We ordered wild mushrooms, ham croquetas and patatas bravas. The mushrooms were disappointing as they were a bit slimy with little flavour. The Ham croquetas were poor with very little meat. The bravas...
review_full: We were recommended this restaurant by someone who had been here previously. We ordered wild mushrooms, ham croquetas and patatas bravas. The mushrooms were disappointing as they were a bit slimy with little flavour. The Ham croquetas were poor with very little meat. The bravas though we're the worst we have ever had, especially as one of the party is a Spaniard.  Overall we were very disappointed and so decided to make an exit and get tapas elsewhere. Then the bill was presented as can be seen. We were shocked to see we had been charged €10 for wet bravas which can only be described as having tomato ketchup on. The Spaniard in our party then complained to the waiter who essentially said 'tough' and his whole manner became disappointgly dismissive. This left a sour taste as no apology was offered. I wouldn't recommend this restaurant, as it was very expensive for very poor food.

review_preview: Intimate restaurant where Alfonso, the chef welcomed us, brought our wine, and suggested some tapas, before returning to his kitchen to prepare our choices! We began with Salmorejo – certainly the best we’ve had while visiting Spain! I could have made a meal with more...
review_full: Intimate restaurant where Alfonso, the chef welcomed us, brought our wine, and suggested some tapas, before returning to his kitchen to prepare our choices! We began with Salmorejo – certainly the best we’ve had while visiting Spain! I could have made a meal with more of this delicious cold soup! But more amazing flavors were coming! The Tomate dulce, which was a surprising blend of flavors and textures, could easily have been our dessert. Next we shared the Tataki de salmon and the Coca de sardine ahumada. Both were excellent, and I was wishing we had ordered one for each of us! Yet, sharing these four delicious tapas, allowed us enough appetite to share an entre, Picana de ternera rosada. A perfect portion to share, the most tender beef with a nice, gentle salsa. HIGHLY recommend this restaurant!

title_review: Great Find in Chueca -  Great Taste and Excellent Value
review_preview: I was walking through the Chueca neighborhood looking for a new Plate de Dia choice and found Vietnam24, but just barely.  It is easy to walk right past it, as it doesn't stick from the other stores and restaurants on the street.  I first looked...
review_full: I was walking through the Chueca neighborhood looking for a new Plate de Dia choice and found Vietnam24, but just barely. It is easy to walk right past it, as it doesn't stick from the other stores and restaurants on the street.  I first looked at the menu and saw the lunch special priced at 10 Euro, plus a vino and dessert. Although the menu I had was only in Spanish, it was easy to make out and had 6 entradas and the same number of second dishes.  The waiter was quick, pleasant and efficient and I was soon off to tasting my pork egg roll and then later, my second dish of noodles/vegetables and chicken. Everything was very tasty with just the right amount of spices. At the end, I was offered coffee or a desert and chose the apple pie. It was served chilled with some fresh whipped cream. This was all for 10 Euros in a pleasant setting. So, the fact that I'm writing a review at all is telling, as I have to have a very favorable impression of a venue to take the time to do this and I wanted to share my experience for others to try. I will be back, as this location is nearby my residence and I look forward to trying their other selections.

title_review: Traditional Spanish Food that Doesn't Disappoint!
review_preview: We recently visited Spain for a week and a half, visiting multiple regions of the country with our two teenage children. During our visit to Madrid, we visited Cantina La Traviesa twice, which we almost never do as we like to explore various places to...
review_full: We recently visited Spain for a week and a half, visiting multiple regions of the country with our two teenage children. During our visit to Madrid, we visited Cantina La Traviesa twice, which we almost never do as we like to explore various places to fully take in a city. Cantina La Traviesa offers traditional Spanish cuisine in the most authentic way - formal service, attentive waiters, dishes full of flavor, classic atmosphere, and tasty sangria, plus extra surprise tastes beyond what you asked for. I look forward to visiting again, and am thankful for our waiter who took such good care of our table.
